headline: Reserve Bank Cuts OCR to 3% Amid Economic Headwinds; Pay Transparency Bill Passes Despite Coalition Split
summary: Parliament was dominated by major economic news as the Reserve Bank cut the official cash rate to 3 percent, aiming to provide relief to households and businesses. The day also saw significant legislative progress, with a landmark pay transparency bill passing its final reading despite opposition from two government coalition partners. Tensions over public sector pay continued, with teacher strikes forming a contentious backdrop to Question Time debates on the cost of living and industrial relations.

topicSummaries.topic: Reserve Bank Cuts Official Cash Rate to 3% to Stimulate Economy
topicSummaries.content: Finance Minister Nicola Willis announced that the Reserve Bank has cut the Official Cash Rate (OCR) by 25 basis points to 3%, its lowest level in three years. Willis hailed the move as delivering much-needed cost of living relief, stating it would save a family with a $500,000 mortgage around $330 a fortnight. The Reserve Bank is also signalling two further cuts this year. The government's economic narrative was challenged by Labour's Barbara Edmonds, who pointed to a 56.6% increase in KiwiSaver hardship withdrawals and a 37% rise in company liquidations as signs that the recovery is not being felt by all.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Barbara Edmonds (Labour—Mana)
keyExchanges.quote: How can she stand by her statement from March this year that the "recovery is under way" when KiwiSaver members withdrew over $470 million for hardship reasons in the past year, a 56.6 percent increase?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Nicola Willis (Minister of Finance)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, I obviously have concern for any New Zealander who feels that their situation is such that it makes sense for them to have to draw down on their savings. And for those in that position, who have made that choice, that will reflect a range of challenging household circumstances.

topicSummaries.topic: Pay Transparency Bill Passes Third Reading, Banning Pay Secrecy Clauses
topicSummaries.content: A member's bill from Labour's Camilla Belich, the Employment Relations (Employee Remuneration Disclosure) Amendment Bill, passed its third and final reading. The new law will make it illegal for employers to include pay secrecy clauses in employment contracts, protecting employees who voluntarily choose to discuss their pay. The bill received broad support from Labour, National, the Greens, and Te Pāti Māori, but was opposed by government coalition partners ACT and New Zealand First, who argued it was an "abomination" that undermined contract law and would create workplace friction.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Mark Patterson (Minister for Rural Communities)
keyExchanges.quote: Fundamentally, this is an abomination—abomination. We are torching contract law. In fact, this bill did not get past first base with us as soon as we saw... you're, essentially, allowing employees to break contract law, and where does that end in this Parliament?

keyExchanges.speaker: Dan Bidois (National—Northcote)
keyExchanges.quote: I only say this in general terms to demonstrate that not everything that matters is in a contract and not everything that's in a contract actually matters. This law really tries to address that.

topicSummaries.topic: Teacher Strikes Dominate Question Time Amid Public Sector Pay Disputes
topicSummaries.content: With teachers on strike across the country, industrial relations were a flashpoint in the House. Green Co-leader Marama Davidson challenged Prime Minister Christopher Luxon on the government offering teachers a pay rise of just 1 percent while inflation sits at 2.7 percent. The Prime Minister deflected, urging unions to "sit around the negotiating table" rather than strike, and reiterated his government's focus on managing inflation and growing the economy to enable wage growth. Later, Education Minister Erica Stanford defended the government's record, stating billions had been invested to improve conditions for teachers.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Marama Davidson (Co-Leader—Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Can he confirm teachers are striking today because they received a pay offer of 1 percent while inflation is currently at 2.7 percent?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: I'm not going to get in the details of the offer—that should be something that's discussed around the negotiating table—but I think what we can all agree on is that our kids have missed out on a huge amount of education.

topicSummaries.topic: KiwiRail Makes Final $144M Settlement for Cancelled iReX Ferry Project
topicSummaries.content: Rail Minister Winston Peters announced that KiwiRail has made a final settlement payment of $144 million to Hyundai for the cancelled iReX ferry project. He described the project, approved by the previous government, as a "sorry saga of mismanagement" that spent a total of $671 million with little to show for it. Peters claimed that cancelling the project, which Treasury forecast could have cost up to $4 billion, had saved taxpayers billions and that the government's alternative solution would secure the future of the Interislander service.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Winston Peters (Minister for Rail)
keyExchanges.quote: Look, if you listen, you'll finally learn. I know it's taken a long time for you, being so inexperienced in this business, having offered yourself for an Auckland mayor when you were a teenager and you didn't know how to run the school tuck shop.

topicSummaries.topic: Major RMA Reform Bill Receives Royal Assent
topicSummaries.content: The government's contentious Resource Management (Consenting and Other System Changes) Amendment Act was given Royal Assent, officially passing it into law. Minister Chris Bishop stated the reforms would make it "quicker and simpler" to consent renewable energy, housing, and primary sector projects, ending decades of the RMA holding New Zealand back. The government also confirmed it had controversially put coal and gas on the same priority consenting pathway as wind and solar to ensure energy security.

keyExchanges.speaker: Simon Court (ACT)
keyExchanges.quote: Minister, why has the Government put coal and gas on the same priority consenting pathway as wind and solar, and will this make it easier to build the firm, affordable power that households and businesses rely on?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Chris Bishop (Minister responsible for RMA Reform)
keyExchanges.quote: The Government has made this decision because we know that when the wind doesn't blow and the rain doesn't fall, New Zealanders need and deserve energy security, and in the New Zealand energy system that means thermal electricity, that means coal and gas...

topicSummaries.topic: Family Violence Evidence Bill Passes Unanimously
topicSummaries.content: A member's bill aimed at protecting victims of family violence in court passed its third and final reading with unanimous support from all parties. The Evidence (Giving Family Violence Evidence in Family Court Proceedings) Amendment Bill, in the name of Labour's Dr Tracey McLellan, creates an automatic presumption that victims can give evidence in alternative ways, such as via video link or from behind a screen. The change is designed to prevent victims from being re-traumatised by having to face their abusers directly during Family Court proceedings, shifting the burden from the victim to the court to provide a safe environment.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Defends Pasifika Unemployment and $22M Programme Cut
topicSummaries.content: Social Development Minister Louise Upston faced sharp questioning from Labour's Carmel Sepuloni over a significant increase in Pasifika unemployment, which has doubled since the government took office. Sepuloni challenged the Minister on the decision to cut $22 million from the Tupu Aotearoa programme, a specific Pasifika employment initiative. Upston defended the cut, stating she did not regret it and that the programme's functions were being absorbed into the Ministry of Social Development to be delivered more effectively, as part of the government's wider focus on growing the economy.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Carmel Sepuloni (Deputy Leader—Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Does she regret her Government cutting $22 million out of a proven programme to help Pasifika into employment, the Tupu Aotearoa programme, given Pasifika unemployment has doubled since this Government took office?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Louise Upston (Minister for Social Development and Employment)
keyExchanges.quote: No, because what our Government is focused on is ensuring that where there is a focus on employment, like the Ministry of Social Development, we are leveraging existing programmes to make them stronger and more effective and ensure we drive better outcomes for Pasifika unemployment.

topicSummaries.topic: Medsafe Approval Times Cut by Over 100 Days
topicSummaries.content: Associate Health Minister David Seymour announced that Medsafe has significantly improved its performance, cutting medicine approval times by over 100 working days over the last two years. He also signalled that legislation to introduce a "Rule of Two" would be brought to Parliament early next year. This rule would mean that if a medicine has been approved by two comparable international jurisdictions, such as Australia or Canada, it will be automatically approved for use in New Zealand within 30 days, further speeding up access to new treatments for patients.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon David Seymour (Associate Minister of Health)
keyExchanges.quote: And for the member who has just sprung into life—although perhaps not mentally—

keyExchanges.speaker: Speaker
keyExchanges.quote: No, that's it. That's the end of the question. That's the end of the question. The member will sit down.

topicSummaries.topic: Major Electricity Market Overhaul Announced to Boost Competition
topicSummaries.content: Energy Minister Simon Watts highlighted a major change to the electricity market announced by the Electricity Authority, aimed at increasing competition and lowering power prices. The new rule will require large generation companies to offer their electricity contracts to all retailers at the same price, preventing them from cross-subsidising their own retail arms. The government hopes this will level the playing field, allowing smaller retailers to compete more effectively and ultimately give consumers more choice and relief from high energy costs.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Shane Jones (Minister for Resources)
keyExchanges.quote: To the Minister for Energy, what other recent announcements has he seen about energy competition flowing from the cancellation of the oil and gas industry?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Simon Watts (Minister for Energy)
keyExchanges.quote: What is very clear as a result of the cancellation of the oil and gas ban is that at long last, certainty is returning to the investment community. It is clear that this country needs a diversity of fuel sources in order to keep the lights on...

topicSummaries.topic: Carter Trust Bill Updating 1961 Act Passes First Reading
topicSummaries.content: The Carter Trust Amendment Bill, a local bill concerning a Wairarapa-based charitable trust for aged care, passed its first reading with unanimous cross-party support. Sponsored by National's Mike Butterick, the bill seeks to modernize the trust's founding 1961 Act, reducing administrative complexity and removing outdated provisions, such as the requirement to seek Minister of Health approval to amend its rules. The changes are intended to allow the trust, which provides housing and care for over 100 residents, to better serve the Carterton community.

conclusion: The government celebrated a key interest rate cut as a sign of economic progress, while simultaneously navigating a clear split with its coalition partners to pass a progressive pay transparency law.
